PM11:04am

Wear premium clothes without the hassle of trawling the internet or the high street.
1. Have a 10-minute phone call with a stylist.
2. Receive what they’ve chosen for you in 3–5 days.
3. Try on your stylist’s picks at home.
4. Keep what you love and we’ll collect the rest for free.

BE11:04am

Like a personal shopper thing? K.

PM11:04am

Our Story
The Chapar concept originated from a father and son who believed that the way men buy clothes is fundamentally flawed. Frankly, men don’t like to shop. They don’t like shopping on the high street and they don’t like shopping online.

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Joe Middleton, a veteran of the clothing industry knew there must be ‘a third way’ and The Chapar is it. Personalised outfits delivered to your door.

The Chapar Man is serviced by a team of Personal Stylists who learn everything they need to know about their client. Clothes are selected according to an intimate profile and are tailored to suit a particular lifestyle.

The Chapar Man knows what he wants and now he know where he can get it.

Personal styling. No shopping.

PM11:05am

It's for men with too much money and no taste

BE11:05am

Not my bag, nor I assume yours, but I'm sure there's a market out there for it. Some people miss the certainty they had as toddlers of having other people dress them.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Here's Credit Suisse on why the UK's a bit better now, relatively speaking.

PM11:12am

Do share

BE11:13am

Polls have suggested an increasing support for the Conservatives. Two polls over the Easter weekend put the Conservatives 21 points ahead of Labour. This is likely to greatly increase the existing working majority of 17 for the Conservatives.

 In the short term, the general election is unlikely to have a major effect on growth. We expect this to be different from a 2015 style general election where uncertainty weighed on growth as 1) the results are likely to be more predictable, and 2) time is too short for the uncertainty to have much effect on growth. Hence we continue to expect a growth slowdown as inflation squeezes household spending and the BoE to remain on hold throughout 2017.

 But the general elections are likely to have an effect on the Brexit negotiations. If Theresa May wins it would be a powerful mandate for her and her type of Brexit, which in turn would limit the ability of either the pro-EU or furiously anti-EU sects of the Conservative party to derail her Brexit. This could mean that it might be slightly easier for Theresa May to give some concessions in the Brexit negotiations and possibly deliver a softer Brexit than the one she has outlined so far.

 Moreover if the Conservatives win, they will have until 2022 before there is another general election. That could cover the full post-Brexit "implementation" period and if they win, they would be able to steer the UK through a full Brexit. If they were to have an election in 2020, as was the initial plan, then there would have been an election mid "transition" period, which would have - in theory - allowed a change of course if a pro-soft-Brexit government was formed. If the Tories win this, that rules out that possibility.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Which dovetails into Garthwaite's latest regional rejig.

BE11:14am

Over the past seven months, cyclical regions have unusually underperformed cyclical sectors. Hence, despite still being cautious on non-financial cyclical sectors, we would look to gain cyclical exposure by being overweight the cyclical regions (i.e. Japan, GEM and Continental Europe).

BE11:15am

§ Continental Europe: Top of our composite scorecard and our top overweight. Growth in 2017 could, as in 2016, be above that of the US. The growth differential on our house view of 2% euro area GDP growth implies 16% outperformance of Continental European equities relative to global equities. Valuations are supportive; a rise in Bund yields would see Europe outperform and earnings revisions are close to a six-year high. The policy backdrop appears set to remain supportive. European inflows remain muted, although picking up. We add to Spain, stick to our overweight of France, downgrade Germany to benchmark and become more underweight of Italy.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

§ GEM: Add to overweight. In terms of macro drivers, GEM should be much more resilient than usual to higher US rates given the sharp improvement in current account deficits, while we are not USD-bullish. GEM assets remain cheap:

currencies are 28% cheap (ex RmB) against the dollar; sector-adjusted P/E discounts are 18% below DM (close to 12-year lows) and real bond yields remain high relative to DM. Structurally, GEM is changing for the better: unit labour costs are falling and some capital discipline is being seen. Disruptive technology increases the formal economy and working capital efficiency, and allows rates to fall. Only 13% of post-2011 outflows have reversed. On a country level, Chinese equities stand out. We would also recommend Korea and India within a global context. Taiwan offers risk hedging characteristics.

§ UK: Raise to benchmark. The UK has now risen to second place on our valuation scorecard. The UK's performance is driven by (in order of importance): weak sterling (unlikely to appreciate much from here), GEM and commodities (CS forecasts 11% upside for oil). The catch is that we think UK GDP growth is set to disappoint (CS forecasts 1.4% GDP growth in 2017), but this would also help to cap sterling. General retail looks very cheap, and we see a long transition period for Brexit. We continue to favour UK euro earners.

BE11:16am

§ Japan: Slightly reduce overweight. The rate of QQE has slowed, Abe's labour market de-regulation is fading, and the global cyclical backdrop has become more complex for the most cyclical global market, with ISM new orders at a peak. We struggle to see yen downside (the key driver of relative performance). We still want to be overweight, however, reflecting our view that US yields will rise from here. Japan has the most compelling funds flow story (corporates and the BoJ are buying a combined c3% of market cap), there are clear signs of corporate change and Japan scores at the top of our regional valuation scorecard. It is the cheapest region on EV/EBITDA and 56% of companies trade below replacement value.

§ US: We remain underweight ex tech. It scores bottom on our composite scorecard. It is an overly defensive market pricing in a sharp slowdown in global GDP growth. Furthermore, it is the region where labour is closest to getting pricing power; monetary policy is normalising; and corporate leverage is back to its previous peak (with buyback as a style underperforming).

PM11:19am

The broader environment

It's arguable that yesterday's announcement adds a further degree of complexity for investors as they consider the outlook for Europe in the months ahead. This, in turn, comes against a broader backdrop of rising geopolitical uncertainty and questions over how many times the FOMC will hike rates this year. It also comes at a point when the USD rally is approaching 6 years old while the bull market in equities is now over 8 years old. From a positioning perspective our own iFlow data show investors remain significantly short of both the GBP and EUR while USD long positions remain extended. The current market is also defined by low volatility, an environment that is often seen as encouraging risk taking. Finally, all this comes at a point in the year when a degree of seasonal risk reduction can become a factor ("sell in May and go away").

PM11:19am

Given this back drop it is interesting to note that while GBP was the major mover over the past 24 hours, it was not the only thing on the move. It was noticeable that bond yields (particularly in the US) remained under pressure. As a result the yield gap between 2-year US government debt and the Japanese equivalent continued to narrow yesterday, hitting levels last seen in early February (it has come in by close to 25 bs since early March). It was also noticeable that the JPY remained strong while even the EUR managed to make gains against the USD despite the looming first round of the French presidential election.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Simon Derrick

PM11:19am

Oh and some krona history

PM11:20am

There have been 8 distinct occasions since the Nixon shock when GBP has risen by 16% or more against the USD over a 26 week period (based upon Reuters data). On 2 occasions (1985, 19908) when GBP rose more than 20% and one occasion (1985) when it rose more than 30%.
GBP spent from early July and late August 1984 trading between USD 1.30 and USD 1.34. When it finally resumed its downtrend at the very end of August it took six months for it to reach its recorded all-time closing low of USD 1.0520 (hit in March 1985). However, the recovery was equally rapid and equally brutal. By the end of April 1985 GBP had come close to hitting USD 1.30 while it stood above USD 1.40 by the end of September of that year.

We continue to target 8000 for mid-18 FTSE 100. The Only Way is Equity.

BE11:26am

We believe the UK housebuilding sector is in rude health. It seems to have brushed off the first Brexit challenge and orderbooks are strong as we start to delve into Article 50. Help to Buy has created a two-speed housing market with the new build sector the beneficiary until at least 2021. With highly visible cashflows we believe that cyclicality is on hold for at least a couple of years and we are comfortable in raising our price targets as a result.

The UK Housebuilding sector remains cyclical, but Help to Buy is smoothing the cycle. The difference in the new build and second-hand market is seldom as stark as it is today. Help to Buy provides a huge competitive advantage to potential purchasers, offering a bank of Mum and Dad to all who need one, which coupled with the lack of upward chains makes new build a honey pot for first-time buyers.

What Referendum? Forward orderbooks do not seem to have been impacted by the EU referendum, which is at odds with the commentary from UK estate agents suggesting that the wider housing market is subdued. However, the new build market only accounts for around 11% of housing transactions and with the second-hand market stagnating it appears that demand from those wishing to buy outweighs the housebuilders ability to supply.

Land, opportunities likely to get even better. Five years after the National Planning policy was introduced, just 37% of English Local Authorities (excluding London) have a sound plan in place, 41% have no plan, 18% have plans submitted and 4% have had their plans rejected. 65% of the English population lives in authorities without a sound plan. The White Paper may have lacked bite, but, in our view, the government will start using it as a stick to get 5-year plans in place and the first beneficiaries of this stick will be the housebuilders as land with planning becomes more plentiful.

Price target changes. In our mind, the stage is set for a golden period for the UK housebuilders with demand outstripping supply (placing upward pressure on the price of homes) and increased land supply where the country most needs homes (placing downward pressure on the price of land). We are, therefore, comfortable in raising the multiples on which our price targets are based. P/B multiple to 1.6x from 1.5x, our PER from 10x to 11x and also adjusting the likelihood of our Neutral, Bull and Bear cases from 1/3, 1/3, 1/3 to 4/10, 4/10, 2/10 as cyclicality appears to be on hold. On average our price targets move up by 20%.

About 4,000 households in England earning more than £100,000 annually are in the Help to Buy Equity Loan scheme.
Official figures to December 2016 show more than 20,000 households who are not first-time buyers have been helped.
The initiative, which started in April 2013, aims to make buying a home more affordable.
But research conducted for the government found 57% of those who signed up to it said they could have afforded to buy without access to the scheme.

BE11:29am

UBS with the quick summary.

BE11:29am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: H2 sales of £1,607m missing expectations (UBSe: 1,619m) by 1%.

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Q4 retail LFL +2% (UBSe 3%, cons 5%) with space 0% (UBSe 3%). H2 wholesale organic -13% (UBSe -15%). Regionally, Q4 LFL was impacted by the US down HSD vs. LSD in Q3 due to a shorter markdown period and Korea was a drag on APAC.

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Underlying FY17 adjusted PBT guidance is unchanged, with FX an additional £10m benefit since the January update. Based on 31 March rates, consensus FY18 PBT of £480m is only expected to slightly decrease due to FX moves with underlying cost efficiencies offsetting. H1 wholesale guided at flat ex-beauty (better than UBSe -7%).

Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Following very strong Q1 results from LVMH last week, expectations were high into numbers and we see the weak LFL weighing on sentiment today despite no underlying downgrade.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And RBC with the slightly longer one.

BE11:29am

Summary: Q4 retail LFL looks soft relative to increased market expectations post LVMH Q1
Burberry retail comps were up 2% in Q4 (against an easy comparative), slowing sequentially from up 3% in Q3 and coming below consensus at +5% (which moved higher following LVMH stronger than expected Q1 sales). Growth in Mainland China and the UK was not enough to offset sales declines in Hong Kong and Americas (which decelerated sequentially from low single-digit comps decline in Q3 to mid-single digit decline in 2H). Wholesale underlying decline of 13% and licensing underlying decline of 38% were both in line with expectations. The company does not expect FY17 consensus PBT to change at FY16 rates and is flagging a slightly higher FX benefit to adjusted earnings (£130m at 31 March rates vs. £115m at the time of its Q3 IMS).

Re. FY18 guidance, Burberry is guiding no contribution from new space in retail (vs. +1.5% in our model), mid-single digit underlying wholesale decline in 1H (in line with our expectations and reflecting some disruption in Beauty) and +20% growth in licensing (reflecting the change in Beauty from wholesale back to licensing). The sterling is expected to turn into a headwind of £10m using 31 March spot rates (from a tailwind of £20-30m at its Q3 IMS) and the FX environment remains volatile (GBP/USD moved

2% against the stock yesterday).

On balance, a relatively soft Q4 performance (at least compared to LVMH), further wholesale drag in the short term and FX – which saved the day in FY17 – is becoming a headwind in FY18. Conference call starts at 9am UK time.

BE11:30am

RBC fundamental view – Sector Perform

Burberry's equity story is centred on increasing retail productivity and leveraging its digital edge to expand into e-commerce. Sterling weakness post UK referendum saved in recent quarter given uneven retail LFL performance and significant wholesale pressure but the sterling should turn into a tailwind in FY18. We see the UK luxury market slowing down in the second half of calendar 2017 and we continue to see better sales and earnings momentum elsewhere in our coverage. That said, Burberry shares seem supported by improving Chinese cluster trends for the sector, cost savings, share buybacks and senior management changes this year.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

the fine-print of 2016 annual reports indicates that most Big Oil companies still believe in 70-80s oil prices longer term. This is not to say the companies can’t manage at lower prices (as recent strategic updates all claim), but it does suggest the sweet-spot of their financial firepower – and therefore higher returns to shareholders – still requires significant price recovery. In our view, 2017, three years into this downturn and where the rapid restart of US shale looks set to threaten the upside in this cycle, might be where those expectations get re-set.

BE11:47am

we think a 20-25% cost take-out looks needed to truly align these businesses to a world where shale caps oil’s recovery to the 50-60s, not much higher than it is today. That looks do-able, but a deepening of structural reforms is surely too going to have to address the high cost of dividends that have – for the most part – not yet been re-set. Dividend resets are painful but, we think, will ultimately prove cathartic; we see COP as a good case-study of a company that has made the necessary choices. We increasingly question the rationale behind companies with more stretched balance sheets and high dividend payouts defending equity at the expense of balance sheet repair and future investment.

BE11:47am

for some time we have questioned the low ratio of capex to dividend at RDS (an implied 1.5x in the core Upstream business vs peers at 3.2x). We think the risk is that RDS is rebalancing to lower oil by underinvesting in its future, and the mistake is for investors to use the dividend yield (7%) as a valuation tool; in reality that yield can easily expand as the market absorbs the risk of shrinkage. On other value-metrics (e.g. EV/IC vs CROCI/WACC) the equity looks expensive. We lower our terminal growth rate from 0.5% to 0%, set spot GBP/USD to 1.27 and lower our DCF-based target from 2070p to 1850p/share (A/B shares).

11:47 am

BE11:48am

while the BP portfolio looks to offer better mid-term growth options than at RDS, and there is more to play with on valuation, the financial leverage (2.6x 17E net debt/18E CFFO @ $55/bbl oil vs peers 1.6x) puts more risk to equity in this environment. At current oil prices another 6% equity dilution – through scrip dividends – looks likely just to balance the books. We set spot GBP/USD to 1.27x and adjust our DCF-based price target from 510p to 480p.

BE11:50am
